objectives: Use polite language in medical contexts

sections.text: When you visit a doctor, you need to tell them which part of your body is hurting or feeling unwell. Knowing the names of your body parts in English helps you explain your problem clearly to the doctor. This is very important for the doctor to understand and help you.
usage_examples: My head hurts badly.
I have a pain in my stomach.
My chest feels tight.
My back is aching from working in the field.
I fell and hurt my leg.
My hand is swollen.
I have a cut on my arm.
My foot is painful when I walk.
I cut my finger while chopping vegetables.
My ear is ringing.
My eyes are red.
My nose is blocked.
I have a sore throat.
My tooth is aching all night.
My neck is stiff.
I have pain in my shoulder.
My knee hurts when I bend it.
I twisted my ankle.
My wrist is painful.
I hit my elbow on the door.

sections.text: When you are sick, you experience certain 'symptoms'. Symptoms are signs that tell you something is wrong with your body. Knowing common illnesses and their symptoms in English will help you describe your problem to the doctor accurately.

table.title: Common Symptoms and What They Mean
rows: Forced air from lungs, can be dry or with phlegm.
Pain inside the head, can be dull or sharp.
Feeling low on energy, tired, unable to do work.
Food or liquid coming out of the mouth from the stomach.
Pain or scratchy feeling in the throat, hurts to swallow.
Feeling unsteady, like the room is spinning.
A part of the body looks bigger than normal due to fluid or injury.
Red, irritated, or bumpy areas on the skin.

sections.text: Before you meet the doctor, you might need to make an appointment or tell the clinic staff why you are there. Always be polite when you greet the doctor or the staff. A polite start makes the conversation smooth.

examples.value: I need to see the doctor.

examples.label: Making appointment
examples.value: Can I make an appointment to see the doctor?

examples.label: Greeting staff
examples.value: Excuse me, I have an appointment.

examples.label: First time visit
examples.value: I am here for the first time.

examples.label: Confirming appointment
examples.value: My name is [Your Name], I have an appointment for 10 AM.

Good morning, Doctor. How are you?

sections.text: After checking you, the doctor will give you 'medicine' and 'treatment'. It is important to understand these words so you know how to get better. Medicine can be in different forms like tablets, syrups, or injections. 'Dose' means how much medicine to take at one time. 'Rest' and 'diet' are also important parts of treatment.

examples.label: Dose
examples.value: खुराक (amount of medicine to take at one time)

examples.label: Rest
examples.value: आराम (taking a break from work or activity)

examples.label: Bandage
examples.value: पट्टी (cloth used to cover a wound)

examples.label: Treatment
examples.value: इलाज (the way to make someone better)

examples.label: Follow-up
examples.value: दोबारा मिलना (another appointment to check progress)

sections.text: It is very important to fully understand the doctor's instructions. If you don't understand something, always ask questions politely. Never feel shy or afraid to ask. It is for your health.

topics.title: Polite Language and Closing the Visit

subtopics.title: Polite Phrases in a Medical Setting

sections.text: Always use polite words when talking to the doctor, nurse, or clinic staff. Words like 'please', 'thank you', and 'excuse me' show good manners and help maintain a respectful atmosphere. Remember, they are there to help you.

examples.label: Asking politely
examples.value: Could you please check my blood pressure?

examples.label: Apologizing
examples.value: Sorry to bother you, but I have a question.

usage_examples: Excuse me, Doctor, I have a headache.
Could you please tell me what medicine to take?
Thank you, Doctor, for your help.
Sorry to bother you, but I forgot one instruction.
I will wait patiently for my turn.
That's very kind of you to explain it again.
Yes, Doctor, I understand your instructions.
Please, could you tell me the timings of the clinic?
Good day, Doctor. Thank you for everything.
I really appreciate your advice on my diet.

sections.text: When your consultation is over, it is polite to thank the doctor and indicate that you will follow their advice. A polite closing leaves a good impression and shows your appreciation.

examples.label: Promise to follow
examples.value: I will follow your instructions, Doctor.

examples.label: Combined
examples.value: Thank you for your time, Doctor. Goodbye.

examples.label: Leaving
examples.value: I will take the medicine now. Thank you.

examples.label: See you again
examples.value: See you for the next visit, Doctor.

examples.label: Appreciation
examples.value: I feel much better after talking to you. Thank you.

examples.label: Confirming next steps
examples.value: So, I will collect the medicine from the counter. Thank you, Doctor.

examples.label: Expressing hope
examples.value: I hope to get well soon with your treatment. Thank you.

usage_examples: Thank you, Doctor. I will take this medicine.
I will follow your instructions, Doctor. Goodbye.
Thank you for your time, Doctor. I will rest well.
Goodbye, Doctor. See you next week for the follow-up.
I will take the medicine now. Thank you, Doctor.
Thank you, Doctor. I hope this helps me.
Thank you for everything, Doctor. I feel more confident now.
I will remember all your advice. Thank you.
Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
Goodbye, Doctor. Have a good day.

sections.text: Read this conversation between a patient and a doctor. Notice how the patient describes symptoms and the doctor gives instructions.
usage_examples:
Patient: Good morning, Doctor. I am not feeling well.
Doctor: Good morning. What is the problem? What are your symptoms?
Patient: Doctor, I have a fever since yesterday. My body is aching, and I feel very weak.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Do you have a cough or cold?
Patient: Yes, Doctor, I have a little cough too.
Doctor: Let me check your temperature. (Checks temperature) You have a high fever. (Listens to chest) Take this medicine twice a day after meals. And take complete rest for two days. Don't go to school.
Patient: How many times should I take this medicine, Doctor?
Doctor: Twice a day, morning and evening, after your food.
Patient: When will I feel better, Doctor?
Doctor: You should start feeling better by tomorrow evening. If not, come back. Drink plenty of water.
Patient: Thank you very much, Doctor. I will follow your instructions.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care.

sections.text: Here is another conversation example. This one focuses on a different kind of problem and treatment.
usage_examples:
Patient: Excuse me, Doctor. My hand is paining a lot.
Doctor: What happened? How did you hurt your hand?
Patient: I was working in the field, and a stone fell on my hand. It happened yesterday morning.
Doctor: Let me see. (Examines hand) It looks like a bruise and a little swelling. It's not broken. You need to apply this cream twice a day. And don't use your hand too much for heavy work for a few days.
Patient: How long should I apply the cream, Doctor?
Doctor: Apply it for five days. The pain and swelling should reduce. If the pain continues, come back.
Patient: Should I put a bandage on it?
Doctor: No, just apply the cream. Keep it open if possible. And avoid lifting heavy things.
Patient: Okay, Doctor. Thank you very much for your help.
Doctor: No problem. Get well soon.

sections.text:
Now, let's practice! Work with a partner. One person will be the 'Patient', and the other will be the 'Doctor'.

Patient, you can choose one of these problems:
*   Severe stomach ache and vomiting.
*   A bad cough and a sore throat.
*   Pain in your knee after playing for a long time.

Doctor, you need to ask questions to understand the problem, give advice, and suggest medicine.

Remember to use polite language, describe symptoms clearly, ask clarifying questions, and understand instructions.
usage_examples:
Doctor: What is the problem?
Patient: Doctor, I have a very bad stomach ache and I have vomited twice.
Doctor: Since when are you feeling this way?
Patient: Since morning, Doctor.
Doctor: Take this tablet, one after breakfast and one after dinner. Eat light food, like rice water.
Patient: How long should I take this medicine?
Doctor: Take it for two days. If you don't feel better, come back.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: What seems to be the problem?
Patient: Doctor, I have a very bad cough and my throat hurts.
Doctor: Do you have a fever?
Patient: No, Doctor, no fever.
Doctor: Take this syrup three times a day. And avoid cold water. Drink warm water.
Patient: Should I take this before or after meals?
Doctor: After meals.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: What's wrong with your knee?
Patient: Doctor, my knee is paining a lot after I played kabaddi yesterday.
Doctor: Is there any swelling?
Patient: Yes, a little bit of swelling.
Doctor: Apply this ointment on your knee twice a day, and take this painkiller if the pain is too much. Avoid running for a few days.
Patient: How many times do I take the painkiller?
Doctor: Only if the pain is severe, once a day. Not more than that. And complete rest to the knee for three days.
Patient: Thank you very much, Doctor.
